definition: Western learning
ocean/vast/foreign/silver dollar or coin
to learn/to study/to imitate/science/-ology
oceanography
Western learning (intellectual movement in the late Qing)/also called 洋務運動|洋务运动
old learning/Chinese traditional teaching as opposed to material from the West
sinology/Chinese studies (in foreign schools)/Han Learning, a Qing dynasty movement aiming at a philological appraisal of the Classics
school or academic institution (old)
the first modern Chinese library established in 1898 by William A.P. Martin 丁韙良|丁韪良, becoming the foundation for Peking University library
Confucianism
foreign affairs (in Qing times)/foreign learning
the teaching of Confucius and Mencius
foreign religion (esp. Western Christianity in Qing China)
Fukuzawa Yukichi (1835-1901), prominent Japanese Westernizer, liberal educator and founder of Keio University
Dutch studies (study of Europe and the world in premodern Japan)
Yan Fu (1853-1921), influential Chinese writer and translator of Western books, esp. on social sciences
college of Western learning in late Qing
to abandon the old (Asian) ways and learn from Europe/refers to the ideas that led to the Meiji Restoration and Japan's subsequent colonization projects in Asia
college/school (old)
Tokyo Imperial University (renamed Tokyo University after 1945)
